triples.evidence: The key is that we collect data using two different X-ray spectra.
if we measure the transmitted X-ray signal with spectrum one, we get one equation that depends on A1 and A2. If we measure again with spectrum two, we get a second equation.
And once we know A1 and A2, we can reconstruct the attenuation coefficient at any X-ray energy.
So how do we actually perform a dual-energy measurement? The key is that we collect data using two different X-ray spectra. Let's call them spectrum one and spectrum two.

evidence: The reconstruction of a1(x,y) and a2(x,y) requires the measurement of line integrals A1 and A2 at every point in the projections of the object.
